content:
A piece of Monument Valley
with wheels.

And the world's
best-looking car in our hangar.

Good evening,
and we're very sorry.

A couple of weeks ago, The Stig
drove a racing car round our race track,

and all week, the newspapers
have been full of little else.

Look at this one. "Top Gear'yobs'
wreck million-pound car."

Of course the Daily Mail had to
go bigger. "Top Gear'hooligans'."

And I am going to be
a hooligan tonight,

because I am going to show you
how to buy a Volvo diesel
with a substantial discount.
Call that yobbish!

I'm going to be test driving the safest
small family car that money can buy.

We've actually got a bit of a
safety theme going on tonight.

And of course, if you're
talking about safe cars,

you have to talk about
Swedish cars.

They gave us the Saab, with
the big jutting out bottom lip,

and they've given us
a whole load of Volvos,

and now, they've given us
a new type of car.
This is the Koenigsegg,

Sweden's attempt
to land a punch

in the Italian-dominated world
of the supercar.

It's their answer to
Lamborghini, Zonda and Ferrari.

The thing is though, that Ferraris are
built with a zest and a Latin passion.

This is built in a more
Northern European way.

For instance, it's made from autoclaved
epoxy, pre-impregnated carbon fibre.
It's a true semi-monocoque.

The front end is mounted on
a chrome molybdenum subframe

and the engine sits on top of a
machined aluminium dry sump

that's also a supporting beam
for the rear subframe.
That's interesting.

And there's more, too, because none
of this behind-the-scenes technology

has interfered in any way
with what Koenigsegg call

"the general ichthyomorphic
design principle".
These are the aesthetics.

And the best bit
of those aesthetics

are the dihedral synchro-helix
actuation doors.

So, is this the most boring
supercar in the world?
Um... no.

It's lighter,
more aerodynamic,

and amazingly more powerful
than a McLaren F1.

Its supercharged V8
pumps out a simply colossal
655 brake horsepower.

Koenigsegg say it will go
from 0-60 in three seconds dead

and on to a top speed
of 245 miles an hour.

Now, if those figures turn out to be
accurate, this will be, quite simply,

the fastest road car
in the world!

Sadly, our test track isn't long
enough to test the top speed.

The fastest I've ever been down here is
170 miles an hour in the Pagani Zonda.
And it wasn't much fun.

Now, it may sound simple,
driving down a runway flat-out,
but there are problems.

The runway is so wide, it
affects your sense of perspective.

So you sit in there thinking,
"Little bit further, little bit more,

"little bit harder,
little bit more speed."
And then, before you know it,
you end up here,

14 inches from the end of the
runway, and in big, big trouble.

It might look a bit daft, but we put up
some markers to remind me to brake.

Then I waited
until the wind had died down.

And then, I went after
the Zonda's record.

Okay, here we go.
Those G-forces hurt your neck!

I've gotta take as much speed as
I can through this bottom corner.

Onto the main strait
at 112 kilometres an hour.

The supercharger
whacking the fuel out!
Into third!

Up to 7,000rpm
and into fourth.

We're now going 205kph.
And into fifth.

Bit of a bump. It's starting
to weave a little bit here.

Here we go,
258 and into sixth gear.
Brake hard!
Oh, hard!
Engine, whoa!

Now, we've got a little button
here, tells us how fast that was.
280 kilometres an hour!
That's 174 miles an hour.

Four miles an hour faster
than I managed in the Zonda.

So, welcome, everyone, to the
fastest car we've ever tested here.

This goes like nothing
I've ever driven.

And it feels like nothing
I've ever driven!

The clutch is heavy,
the steering's heavy,
the gearbox is heavy.

It's just a tonne and a half
of testosterone.

You could drive this thing to the gym,
turn around, go straight home again,

you'd have had more exercise
than if you'd done a workout.
Touch of understeer.
You've gotta be so fast!
It is absolutely brutal!

A bloke from Koenigsegg
was going,

"Turn the traction
control off."
He must be joking!

This is the meanest,
angriest, heaviest,

most unforgiving machine
I've ever come across.
But it doesn't need to be.

That is the beauty
of this car.

If you don't like something
about it, change it.

The bodywork all peels away,
and then everything is adjustable,

brake bias, suspension, ride
height, power steering, the lot.

So you can have it set up for a big,
wide open circuit like Silverstone one day,

and then the next day,
couple of minutes' work,

and it's set up for a twisty,
turny one like Cadwell Park.

Then, if it's a lovely
summer's evening

and you want to set it up
for going to the pub,
simple, slide in here,

do this clip, move that lever,
undo that clip,
and the roof comes out.

Then you simply slide it
into the front, like so...

Perfect fit.
Still room for a small bag.

Close that down.
And we're ready to go.

The Koenigsegg doesn't have the
racing pedigree of McLaren and Ferrari.

It doesn't have the phantasmagorical
or visual clout of the Lambo
or the quality of a Zonda,

but it's very fast
and very, very special.

Well, it may be a Swede,
but take it from me,
it's not a turnip.

Ah, well.
That is brilliant.

What a fantastic start
to a programme about safety.

That's really going to help
get rid of the headlines.

"Top Gearsensible people,"
it's not gonna say after that.
Thanks.

- He's let us down.
- I'm afraid so, yes.

He's let the BBC down,
he's let The Stig down,

- he's let himself down.
- He has.

Do you think
we can rescue the reputation

of this safety programme
with a bit of insider dealing?

- I've no idea, give it a shot.
- Okay.

Volvo. Now, deals on new
Volvos in the UK are quite rare.
They are good, steady sellers,

they don't generally have
a problem with oversupply

or any of those things that
tend to drive prices down.

However, let's take
one of their S60 models.

In fact, let's take a really
good, sensible diesel one.
This is the D5S 2.4.

The list price of this,
£21,000. I found it for £17,000.

- That's a good, safe buy.
- Very safe.

Let's try a more
interesting one.

We've got the C70 Convertible
2 litre-T.

That's almost £25,000
list price.
I found it for £22,000.

Now VAT is not something
I normally worry about,

- because, frankly, you can't do anything about it.
- No.

But you can get Citroen
to pay it, it turns out.

Now they won't pay VAT
on fags or whisky,

but they will pay it
on some new Citroens.

Notably,
they're people-carriers.

We've got the small one
which is the Xsara Picasso,

and the big one
which is the C8.

They will also pay the VAT
on any options you specify.

So, if you had a fully kitted-out
Citroen C8 people-carrier,

you would be saving
almost £4,000.

That adds up, doesn't it?
That's a big saving.

Well, let's take
a real life example, okay.

The Xsara Picasso 2-litre HDI
diesel in desire specification.

The list price of this car
is £14,600,

but with Citroen paying
the VAT, it's £12,500.

£2,100 off.
Does that sound good?

- Yeah, that sounds very good to me.
- Good? Good?

Ah, well, you see, I found
the same car in the UK,

the same specifications,
£11,000.
That's even cheaper. Why?

Because I went
through a broker.

Now, you all are seeing these
things in the back of car magazines,

you get them at the back of Exchange
and Mart, you get it on the interwebnet.

These people that advertise
cars at bargain prices,

what you do is you go to them,
you say, "This is the car I want".

They find it for you and they
tell you what their best price is.
You can take it or leave it.

The moral of this is,
always shop around.

Because it doesn't matter how
good the official manufacturer's deal is,

someone else will
probably beat it. Hmm.

Right, let's get back to the safety
theme, and the Koenigs-eugh-egg.

We've established
that it's the fastest car

we've ever tested
in a straight line.

But what about
round the track?

It would have to beat
the Zonda's 1:23.8.
So, can it?
Valkommen...

So,
this is the big one!

Can the Koenigs-eugh-egg take
the lap record round our track?

This car has over 100
horsepower more than the Zonda

and loads of grip, so if
anything can do it, it will be this.

We should never have
let The Stig go to Tennessee.

Now, here we are,
into Chicago.

And he's sideways!
He is very sideways!

Steady, Stiggy,
this car bites!

Coming up to the Hammerhead
now. Will it understeer?
Not a chance! Look at that.

It's the Follow-Through,
he's looking fast.
Oh, that is very fast!

Over the first sector,
the Koenig...

It was absolutely
level pegging with the Zonda.

Can it beat the Pagani
to the end?

Here we go, a bit of a slither
through Gambon and across the line!

So, anyone wanna guess?
Was it faster than the Zonda?

- Yes.
- You're wrong.
It did it in one minute 23.9.
A tenth off.
Just a tenth off.
It's basically the same.

I'll tell you
something though,

it's gonna take me longer than
one minute 23 seconds to write it out.
It's Koenigs...

- K-O-E...
- I've got that.

You carry on with that.
I'll tell you something else.

Who would like to see a shot of The Stig's
first attempt to get across the line?

- Yes.
- Okay. Play it.
Here he comes, up to Gambon.

The extraordinary...
How are you doing?

Well, I've run out of space. I've got
about 12 Gs on there and I can't...

I've got an idea though,
hang on.

Hopeless,
you've got 12 Gs...

- I'll get it on there, I reckon.
- Yeah.

Thing is though, I have to
say about the Koenigsegg,

and this is that, when I
was doing the speed run,

there's a dip in the runway where,
presumably, planes used to land.

And when you head through
that normally, 120, 130, it's fine,

but once you're going
past 160...

And just before I set off
on the speed run...

- What are you doing?
- I missed a G out there.

- Keep going. There's no X in it.
- Is there not?

Just before I did the speed run,
the guys from Koenigsegg said,

"Would you mind awfully, we're going to
put some gaffa tape around the window?"

That really fills you
with confidence!

Still an immensely
impressive car.

Come here, let me finish it off for
you, you're gonna be here all day.

- That can't be...
- Koenigsegg.
I-G-O-G-A-B-B-A.

Oh, that's how...
Yeah, you're right.
Viking CC.

Oh, no, there's no space
for the time.

But it goes... It goes... I was
rather hoping it might not, actually.
Can you reach?
The thing is...

It did it in
one minute 23.9 seconds.
That is so close.

That is fantastic, and I think you
have once and for all established here

that the Koenigsegg-segg-segg-
segg-segg-abba-segg-viking is very, very fast.

- Yeah.
- That's good. But that's not really about safety, is it?

- No.
- No.

Are you planning to do anything
to do with our safety theme at all?

- No.
- Didn't think so.

- Do you wanna try?
- Maybe a bit later. Actually, maybe now.

Because my guest tonight is best-known
for his role in Men Behaving Badly,
but he was once in Boon,

where he had a motorcycle, and
therefore he had a crash helmet.

- Safety! Got it.
- Exactly.

Ladies and gentlemen,
Neil Morrissey!

- Hey! How are you?
- How are you?
Very well. Have a seat.

- Bit of a problem, this.
- Yeah.

Last time we were together about six
weeks ago, we were on the Parkinsonshow.

And we had Parky
to ask us questions.
Now, what are we gonna do?
Do you reckon you're up to it?

I read somewhere, uh,
you read somewhere, uh,

somebody somewhere...
What about your father?

- Jeremy, tell me, you're into cars, apparently.
- Yeah.

Cricket.
Let's talk about cricket.

- Actually, we are talking about safety tonight.
- Yeah.

- Are you a safe driver?
- Well, I'd say I am now.

I mean, I definitely have been through the
whole, sort of, mad area in my life, you know.

I mean, I've always had
motorbikes as well.
Oh, no. Really?
Yeah, come on, man.
Well, they're very fast.

I knew it would happen
one day.

I knew we'd have a guest come on

and I'd have to sit
and pretend to be interested.

No, but the thing is, there's
perfectly good reasons.

And understandable, Jeremy,
why you wouldn't like motorcycles.

- Why?
- Well, you're very tall, aren't you?
Yeah.

You'd look like one of
those clowns on a silly old...

Going round a very gentle
bend, knee on the floor.
"What's that about?"

Do you go on these,
sort of, biker weekends?

No, not really.
But I enjoy the bikes.

I wouldn't say I'm a member of

you know, there's a group of
friends, a few of us who like bikes,

but we don't go...
I mean, you know...

'Cause there is modus operandi
for being a biker, isn't there?

- They all meet...
- Honestly, I live in the Cotswolds, okay?

- And every...
- Great roads around there, for, uh...

No, that's it! Every single
Sunday, out they come!
Well, yeah.
From a 100 miles away!

You can hear them
leaving Edinburgh.

And it's such a stupid noise
that motorbikes make.

You know, as they're driving past

and you're clipping the hedge
with your Black and Decker,

they're just going past you
going, "Sad".
Now, look. The thing is,

I don't spend my weekends dressing
up in leather and going off with other men,

a lot of whom have moustaches,
and then drinking soft drinks in the pub.

Yeah, but... I do have to agree
with you and comply a little bit there,

because there is a certain way
of dressing these days.

We've got some photographs.
Can we just bring up a photograph?

- Oh, yeah.
- This is the sort of thing...

- See, that is dodgy.
- Do you wear that when you...

Oh! Certainly not.
No. Definitely not, no.

I mean, this is
a Power Ranger, isn't it?

This is what they're
dressing like...

Ohh, no! See, that is not
very easy on the eyes.

How do you look cool,
walking into the pub like that?

And going,
"A bitter lemon, please,

"'cause I'm riding
my Honda CBR."
Yeah. Yeah.

- What bike have you got?
- I've got a big, fat Triumph. It's a 955 ST Sprint.

It's about
a couple of years...

That's just a collection of
numbers and letters. Meaningless.

It's a fast little
fella... on the road.

I understand that.
"Fast little fella."

Yeah, but it's great.
It's a nice, light bike.

There's as much variety in the

you know, for the kind of
performance you want to get out of it

'Cause I did once go... You might

I once went on something

- You're familiar with that?
Oh, God, yeah. Yeah.

And it was in Monte Carlo

No, no, but if you did that,

And so, you literally are

Because, I mean,

In the rain, with those

thinking that they're

And what I love doing is,

dual carriageway, the queue, and

Scares the life out of them.

I know! But that's another thing

I'm not jealous.

'Cause you're arriving in a

Yeah, that's true. But you can do

all kinds of things.

It'll take you 20 minutes

Unplugging yourself...

What sort of car
do you drive?
I've got a nice BMW 745i.
That's not very sporty.

No, it's not very sporty,

I mean, I prefer to sort of

I like to go out to race days.
I like to go to race tracks.

- Yeah, track days.

And it is brilliant. And at

Do you think you're down here?

Obviously not

There is an organisation

that, every year, deliberately

It then awards them
